title: Nike Art Gallery
name: Nike Centre for Art and Culture
description: West Africa's largest art gallery, housed in a magnificent four-story building. It holds thousands of artworks including paintings, textiles, and metalwork.
history: Founded by Chief Nike Davies-Okundaye, a world-renowned batik and textile artist, to promote Nigerian culture and empower artists.
best_time_to_visit: Weekdays for a quieter experience; weekends if you want to meet other art lovers.
safety_info: Very safe location. Be careful with delicate artworks when moving through narrow aisles.
available_activities: Art appreciation, purchasing art, meeting the artist (Chief Nike is often there), textile workshops (by appointment).

title: National Museum Lagos
name: National Museum Lagos
description: A museum housing a significant collection of Nigerian art, archaeological findings, and ethno-historical exhibits.
history: Established in 1957, it houses the bullet-ridden Mercedes Benz in which General Murtala Mohammed was assassinated in 1976
safety_info: Located in a secure government zone (Onikan).
available_activities: Viewing historical artifacts (Nok, Benin Kingdom), educational tours, seeing the "Jembewon" car

title: Freedom Park
name: Freedom Park Lagos
description: A memorial and leisure park dedicated to preserving the history and cultural heritage of Nigeria. It was formerly "Her Majesty's Broad Street Prison."
opening_hours: Daily, 11:00 AM – 10:00 PM (Late on concert nights)
best_time_to_visit: Evenings for live band music; December for the "Felabration" or other cultural festivals.
safety_info: Generally safe, but be cautious when leaving late at night on Lagos Island. Contact info: 0809 500 6567
available_activities: Live music, museum tour of old prison cells, dining at the food court, photography, theater performances.

title: Kalakuta Republic Museum
name: Kalakuta Republic Museum
description: The former home of Afrobeat legend Fela Kuti, now a museum displaying his clothes, shoes, instruments, and bedroom exactly as he left them.
history: This was Fela’s residence and commune. It was attacked by soldiers in 1977. Fela is buried in the compound.
best_time_to_visit: During "Felabration" week (October) or any weekday for a personal tour.
safety_info: Ikeja is busy; stick to the museum grounds and official transport.
available_activities: Guided house tour, rooftop bar (chill spot), viewing Fela's tomb, buying souvenirs.

title: Tarkwa Bay Beach
name: Tarkwa Bay Beach
description: A sheltered, artificial beach located near the Lagos Harbour. It is accessible only by boat.
entry_fees: Boat Ride: ₦4,000 – ₦6,000 (Return trip from Victoria Island/CMS)
history: Created during the construction of the Lagos harbor moles (breakwaters) to prevent sand silting up the harbor.
safety_info: Do not stay past 6:00 PM as boats stop running and security decreases. Only swim in designated areas; currents can be strong near the breakwater.
contact_info: N/A (Boat operators at Fiki Marina or Mekwe Jetty)
available_activities: Surfing (popular spot), swimming, volleyball, quad biking, relaxing.

title: Badagry Slave Route
name: Badagry Heritage Museum & Slave Route
description: A collection of historical sites marking the Trans-Atlantic slave trade era. Includes the First Storey Building in Nigeria, Point of No Return, and the Heritage Museum.
history: Badagry was a major slave port. The "Point of No Return" is the path slaves walked to board ships. The First Storey Building (1845) is where the English Bible was translated to Yoruba.
best_time_to_visit: Early morning start (it is a 2-3 hour drive from Lagos mainland).
safety_info: The road to Badagry is currently under construction (as of 2024/25), so travel can be rough. Use a recognized tour guide.
contact_info: Local guides usually available at the museum entrance.
available_activities: Historical education, boat ride to Gberefu Island, walking the slave path, drinking from the "miracle well."

title: John Randle Centre for Yoruba Culture
name: John Randle Centre for Yoruba Culture and History
description: A world-class cultural center and swimming pool complex dedicated to preserving and telling the story of Yoruba heritage.
history: Newly renovated and opened in 2023/2024, revitalizing the old John Randle swimming pool (built in 1928) into a modern museum.
available_activities: Interactive museum exhibits, swimming (pool requires separate fee/membership), cultural storytelling.

title: New Afrika Shrine
name: New Afrika Shrine
description: An open-air entertainment center and the spiritual home of Afrobeat music, managed by Femi and Seun Kuti.
opening_hours: Open 24/7 (Main action is Wed, Thu, Fri, Sun nights)
best_time_to_visit: Thursday (free rehearsal) or Sunday evenings (live performance by Femi Kuti).
safety_info: It is in a raw, energetic part of town. Marijuana smoke is common. Dress casually and avoid flashing expensive gadgets.
available_activities: Live Afrobeat music, dancing, eating local "Suya" and "Jollof," political discussions.

title: Jaekel House
name: Terra Kulture (Arts & Culture Centre)
description: A premier educational and recreational hub featuring an art gallery, a theater for stage plays, a craft shop, and a restaurant serving authentic Nigerian delicacies.
history: Founded in 2003 by Bolanle Austen-Peters to promote Nigerian languages, arts, and culture. It is famous for producing "Saro the Musical" and "Fela and the Kalakuta Queens."
best_time_to_visit: Sunday afternoons (usually when stage plays happen) or lunch time for their famous "Terra Catfish."
safety_info: Located in a secure, high-end area of Victoria Island.
available_activities: Dining, art gallery viewing, watching theatre productions, buying books/crafts.

title: Omu Resort
name: Omu Resort
description: A massive family recreation center combining a zoo, amusement park, and water park. It is one of the most comprehensive fun spots in Lagos.
opening_hours: Mon-Sat: 9:00 AM – 6:00 PM; Sun: 12:00 PM – 6:00 PM
best_time_to_visit: Weekdays to avoid long queues at rides; early morning arrival is recommended as it is far from the city center.
safety_info: Rides are generally well-maintained. Follow zoo safety guidelines strictly.
available_activities: Zoo (lions, hyenas), archery, go-karting, water park, mechanical rides, wax museum, mini-golf.

title: La Campagne Tropicana Beach Resort
name: La Campagne Tropicana Beach Resort
description: A 65-acre African-themed beach resort with a freshwater lake, mangrove forest, and sandy beach. It is known for its "Simi" chalets and traditional architecture.
entry_fees: Corkage Fee: Applies if you bring your own food/drinks.
history: Founded by Otunba Wanle Akinboboye to showcase African hospitality and culture to the world.
best_time_to_visit: Dry season (Nov–Mar) for the blue water experience; holidays for cultural displays.
safety_info: Lifeguards are present, but swim only in designated areas. The drive there is long; ensure your vehicle is in good condition.
available_activities: Kayaking/canoeing in the lagoon, horse riding, swimming, quad biking, cultural dance displays.

title: Lufasi Nature Park
name: Lufasi Nature Park
description: An urban forest park designed for relaxation and nature conservation. It houses the endangered Ekki "Iron Wood" trees and a shelter for Hooded Vultures.
best_time_to_visit: Mornings for bird watching; weekends for picnics.
safety_info: Very safe, enclosed environment. Ideal for children.
available_activities: Forest bathing (nature walks), bird watching, animal sanctuary viewing (monkeys/donkeys), picnics, playground.

title: National Arts Theatre (Wole Soyinka Centre)
name: National Arts Theatre (Renamed: Wole Soyinka Centre for Culture & Creative Arts) State / City / LGA: Lagos State / Iganmu / Surulere LGA
description: An architectural masterpiece shaped like a military hat. Recently renovated (2024/2025), it is Nigeria's primary center for performing arts.
best_time_to_visit: During national holidays or scheduled exhibitions.
safety_info: The area surrounding Iganmu can be rough at night. Use the new "Blue Line" Rail to the National Theatre Station for safe, direct access.
available_activities: Architecture photography, attending cultural expos, riding the Blue Line train.

title: Elegushi Royal Beach
name: Elegushi Royal Beach (Private Beach Fronts)
description: One of the most popular beaches in Lagos, known for its vibrant nightlife, numerous bars, and horseback riding. It hosts various private beach clubs (e.g., Wave Beach, 234Lofts).
opening_hours: 24 Hours (Best active time is afternoon to late night)
history: Owned by the Elegushi Royal Family. It transformed from a local hangout to a major entertainment strip.
best_time_to_visit: Sunday evenings for the party atmosphere.
safety_info: The Atlantic waves here are very rough and dangerous. DO NOT SWIM deep. Be mindful of personal belongings in crowds.
available_activities: Horseback riding, nightlife/clubbing, beach soccer, dining.

title: Cathedral Church of Christ
name: Cathedral Church of Christ, Marina
description: The oldest Anglican cathedral in the Church of Nigeria. Its Norman Gothic architecture and clock tower make it one of Lagos' most photographed landmarks.
history: The foundation stone was laid by the Prince of Wales in 1925, and it was completed in 1946. It houses the largest pipe organ in Nigeria.
best_time_to_visit: Sunday morning (to hear the choir) or Saturday (for exterior photography).
safety_info: Marina is a busy business district. Exercise caution with cameras on the street.

title: Jhalobia Recreation Park & Gardens
name: Jhalobia Recreation Park and Gardens
description: A beautifully manicured garden located between Hajj Camp and the International Airport. It features waterfalls, sculpture, and exotic flowers.
history: Established by Mrs. Veronica Adepoju to provide a serene environment in the chaotic city center.
best_time_to_visit: Weekdays for quiet meditation or reading.
available_activities: Picnics, pre-wedding photography, garden events, botanical walks.

title: Oniru Private Beach
name: Oniru Beach (The Box / Sol Beach)
description: A cleaner, more upscale beach experience compared to public beaches. It features well-organized beach clubs like "Sol by BoxMall."
history: Part of the land owned by the Oniru Royal Family, recently reorganized to be more modern and exclusive.
safety_info: Safer and more controlled environment than Elegushi. Swimming is still risky in the open ocean; use the pools provided by beach clubs.
available_activities: Swimming (pool), beach dining, jet skiing (rentals available), relaxation in cabanas.

title: Tafawa Balewa Square (TBS)
name: Tafawa Balewa Square
description: A ceremonial ground with a distinctive entrance gate featuring giant horses and eagles. It was the site of Nigeria’s independence celebration in 1960.
entry_fees: History: Originally a race course, it was reconstructed in 1972 and named after Nigeria’s first Prime Minister. It housed the National Assembly before the capital moved to Abuja.
Best time to visit: Daytime. It is often used for the "Lagos International Trade Fair" (November) or "The Experience" concert (December).
Safety info: Located in a very busy commercial hub. Watch out for "Area Boys" (street touts) in the surrounding bus stops.
Available activities: Photography of the monuments, shopping (there is a shopping complex inside), attending major concerts.
Address / Access Info: 45/57 Massey Bamgboshe Street, Lagos Island, Onikan/Onikan-Race Course area, Lagos, Nigeria.
Start: National Stadium / Finish: Eko Atlantic
Audience: Professional runners, fitness enthusiasts, general public.
